reviewText:
This game is missing way too many features to be worth it at the current price. wait until its inevitable price of 99 cents or lower, or for a bundle. Its still Risk, and Risk is always fun, but here are some of the problems and things missing that would make this a tolerable PC port.

1. No save feature
2. No resolution or graphics settings, options menu is bare bones with just sound sliders and the ability to turn off animations
3. You cant skip through enemy turns, and if you click too fast to skip, it zooms in and out on the space and nothing progresses
4. camera gets stuck when mouse is over a country
5. turns take too long to animate through

theres probably alot more issues but I didnt have the stomach to sit through them all. the fact that there isnt a 4-pack deal for this game tells you that this developer doesnt know what theyre doing. This is like a watered down version of a Risk game i played on the original Xbox back in 2006. so basically in ten years, the video game version of Risk has somehow gone down in quality.

2/10

reviewText:
WORKS ON WINDOWS 7 DESPITE NOT MENTIONING IT ON STORE PAGE.
(tested on Win 7 64 bit)

With that out of the way: it's Vanilla risk, for the PC and unlike the first stab they took at it on steam, this Risk features multiplayer. You can have up to 4 players any of which can be player or AI. (Actually not sure if you can have 4 AI, didn't try).

Game options are just music volume, fx volume and battle animations on or off. The main annoyance with a game like this, playing it solo, as you might imagine is the tedium of waiting for the AI to take their turn and all the various animations to stop playing. Unfortunately, turning battle animations off only removes a small part of the animations you have to sit through: Each player's turn you have to sit there while they select troops, reinforce places, receive cards and attack. Even with battle animations off you still get the map zooming in to that area, dice being rolled and troops cheering or sighing; you just don't get them firing at each other.

I didn't test multiplayer but I would recommend the game for single player if you like Risk or think you might. Maybe in the future they will add an option to skip more of the animations, but I suspect (no real evidence, but...) that this is a dump it and leave it alone release, as in there will be patches only to fix crashes.

reviewText:
About:

Standard Risk game, looks like the board games plastic pieces, board itself is nice (and 3D, can zoom in and pan around), all mouse (not keyboard) controlled as far as i can tell?

It's fairly nice to play, the different ai choices do seem to actually have different stratgems/personalities as far as I can tell, setting one to chaotic does actually seem to have them make some odd choices.

Will update review once I've tried multiplayer (review so far is based on 2 matches against the ai)
- Although, upon entering the setup for online multiplayer (not local) it appears you have to invite people from your friends list, no matchmaking?
- If someone else could confirm that I haven't simply missed an option for auto invite's I'll update my review to reflect it as a fact?



Critisisms:

NEEDS a way to skip the ai's turns! and could do with some more graphical options?

Would also not be the worst thing if they added the options to adjust all of the different sound volumes individually. (the Din ding! sound upon completing an attack move is much louder than any of the other noises)

Hopefully they'll see our reviews and add this.



Tested on:

(obviously this is overkill for this game)
Windows 8 Pro 64bit
4th gen i7
16gb ddr3
GTX 980ti

Takes a small ammount of time to boot from a black screen but then runs without any problems or glitches (at least thus far).

reviewText:
A decent port of RISK for the PC.

PROS:
* Can be played on a touchscreen (tested it on my T100 Windows tablet).
* Can play against AI or friends.
* Allows for some minor customization of the rules.
* Is fun and entertaining.

CONS:
* A minor nitpick, but when an AI attacks you, you don't get to roll defense dice.  Odd that you roll the attack dice on your own turn.  I'm fine with skipping it, but there should at least be an option to do it if I want.

* Animations can get annoying.  You can turn off battle animations, but not the win/lose animations for the battle.

In the case of this game, the cons are all minor.  It's a good experience for the price.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This is nothing fancy just your typical RISK game that everyone knows and loves. In the current state there are many neat features:

1. Play with up to 3 friends minus yourself or you may play a game against 3 AI opponets with 5 difficulty options for them.

2.The animations for me anyway are fun to watch and gives you something to look at while the AI is playing it's turn. What I like about the animations is that they use the proper models for troop numbers. For instance if you have 6 troops invading a territory it will show up as a calvary soldier (represents 5 troops) and a regular soldier (represents one troop). To me small things like that make the game more real to me.

3.When attacking a region you have two options, you may do a standard roll the dice or use the auto resolve feature which is basically giving the battle up to fate to see who wins. The only major issue I have with this game is that the AI does not use the retreat feature when they are losing a battle, they just throw troops away and are not conservative players even on the highest difficulty.

4. So far I've played two AI games and enjoyed both equally with the AI always keeping me on my toes. Some intelligence is shown should one player become to powerful, if you take a continent the AI will happily band together to take away that bonus from you. It shows some thought and logic, they want to keep the game moving and not let one person or AI become more powerful.

5. I have no friends that own the game, so I do not know if you can save those games. But you may save one game at a time while playing against AI opponents, which allows you to return to the game at a later time should something come up.

6. Also the game has a bunch of cool sounds for turn starts, conquering or losing a region, and sounds during the animated fights.

I would rate this a 7/10, but I mean it's worth the buy, 7 bucks for a digital version of a classic board game isn't too much in my book. No matchmaking is in the game but the developers have said they are going to add it within the coming weeks.

reviewText:
Basic vanilla game of RISK.  Great for a short (or long) game against hotseat or online with friends.  There is another older RISK version on steam but I have never played that version.

Pros:
-It's RISK - The Game of Global Domination
-Pleasing board and visuals.
-Autorolls all defense and fast forwards AI turns (not skips but faster than watching dice roll)
- Fair statistics for computer/human rolls.  Pleased to see


Cons:
-Ukraine isn't just weak but it's been replaced by Russia - weak Ukraine so weak...
-Only 4 players - not up to 6
-The last game of Risk I had was for Windows 95  and it had multiple settings (Capital, same time risk, ect) This version only has Classic and a Fast game option
-Did they change the way cards are played?  Armies determined by amount of cards turned in, not by order and no country army bonus for territories (gives that option in game setup but i didn't see it applied).
-Would like the intro music to continue throughout the game to cover the army cheering

reviewText:
This game really isn't worth €7:

-The online Multiplayer doesn't work: it crashes all the time, dice don't load, out of sync,...

-You can't save the game (which in my opinion would be the only plusside compared to the real life boardgame)

-If you try skipping AI turns -which isnt possible- the screen starts to zoom in and out

-The whole aspect of making deals with other players can not be done. It would be nice if there would just be afeature to make a deal with the AI. ex: 5 turns of peace or something like that.

-IF you even consider playing the game in MP, you can play in the same room with someone on the same PC, and play a local MP... But than again, WHY play the game on the PC then? Why dont you just play the boardgame if you're together??

This is a really poor attempt to make a Risk game on PC.

3/10

reviewText: I like this remake.  I've owned most of them.  The Best being Risk 2, the worst:  Risk Factions.\nThe new animations in this Risk version are entertaining and look nice in HD.  It's solo AI game is a blast.  I've read so many reviews poo pooing the game that say you can't click through the AI turns."  They attempt to imply that the AI turns last a very long time and that you have to watch AI dice rolls for hours on end.  Either these people never played the game or simply dont understand how to play.  THE AI USES FAST DICE MODE ON EVERY ATTACK.  Read that line again.  When the AI attacks another AI
date: you just see the victory of the Winning AI either conquering or defending the country.  So the AI turns go really fast
recommended: no dice rolls to watch what-so-ever!  Players can use fast attack dice mode too when attacking AI
hoursPlayed: so it goes really fast this way also.  In fact the only time you actually have to roll the dice is when you are defending against the AI or attacking/defending against another player.  I found the rounds go pretty fast.\nI'm reserving judgement on this game until they fix the net code for multiplayer
voteText: and add a solid player matching service.  But for the price you can't beat it as a solo game.  Perfect for long trips with a laptop in plane or a car.  For me its a 7/10 as is."
